pros: I love the autonomy provided by my supervisor.
cons: Lots of driving across the sate!

review_title: Great Company, poor culture being developed in IT
pros: Great mission Individual contributors care about mission Great CEO, cares about employees
cons: IT Leadership, starting with CIO, is beginng to create a poor culture. This culture starting to emerge is a culture of fear and stiffeling innovation. Hopefully, it will be caught in time before it gets too bad and too many people leave. Individual contributors are great and kind, it is just Senior leaders that I feel are struggling with creating strategy and managing culture.

job_title: Bilingual Public Response Project Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: There are many amazing people that work here and are talented
cons: There are toxic supervisors running public response that bash pagan religions and are racist. When reported to HR the supervisor stated the issue was my work performance when none of the other supervisors I worked with ever reported anything wrong and this was the first I had heard of it. For months the supervisor would say I wasn't doing good enough and those whom I worked with said opposite. It was mentally draining and finally I asked for a final verdict on my work ethic vs me being told I wasn't good enough everyday when I was going above and beyond solely because I had gotten on this supervisors bad side. This company turned its back on me.

pros: The company is non profit which whole purpose is to find bone marrow donor matches and save lives. The work culture is very welcoming and there is plenty of room to grow in the company.
cons: Starting out as a lab tech it is very repetitive and boring work but the people you work with can make the day go by quickly. You will be able to do more interesting work if you stick around for 4 months.

review_title: Truly is the best job ever!
pros: The organization's mission and everyone's dedication to the mission is incredible. Management really cares about employees and talent. Leadership and supervisors are great. In my position, I have had no issues with micro-management and I feel I am trusted to do my job from home. I always feel appreciated for the work I do and the work is meaningful. Also worth mentioning, great benefits, compensation, and generous PTO.
cons: 1. Work load can be overwhelming at times. 2. Career growth / paths are not extremely clear, but I do see the organization making more efforts lately in that area.

pros: The training for the DOS role was impeccable. Everyone I have encountered has been wonderful to work with. The IT department is amazing especially with a remote job. The upper management shows great appreciation for every individual.

job_title: Training and Development Specialist in Minneapolis, MN

review_title: Great mission and ambitious company goals at the cost of disjointed management and poor appreciation for employees.
pros: The cause is truly a great and noble one, and the company does a stellar job anchoring everyone's work to the core mission. By and large, employees across the board have a genuinely high fidelity to the patients/donors/cause. Communication and transparency from the top down is better than most companies. Benefits are good.
cons: Teams & departments are constantly moving within the company, restructuring, and/or being renamed, which leads to a lot of confusion and eventual eye-glazing regarding the organizational structure. Despite broad buy-in for the work people do, employees often do not feel valued by management and there is limited actual upward mobility. Communication from the executive team is solid but is lacking from people managers. IT is woefully stretched thin and it is not uncommon to find the only people in the entire company who understand how a software program works are the business users on one team (i.e. IT support understanding might range from limited to none at all).

job_title: Senior Business Lead in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great benefits and bonuses. Ability to work remote. 32 days PTO. Pension. Fly on courier trips around the world.
cons: Non-profit pay but plenty of PTO time!

pros: Time off policy and benefits are outstanding. Open to remote work, finally!
cons: While cutting edge, there are still some departments that run in circles.

review_title: Challenging and rewarding call center environment
job_title: Donor Operations Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
A great mission
Decent pay and benefits
Helpful, understanding, and supportive managers
24 days of PTO - you're encouraged to take your time off
Lots of opportunities to move within the organization
Work from home - all equipment provided
They like to shower you with freebies periodically 
Inclusive and very forward-thinking
cons:
Call center environment - non stop inbound calls where you're "kicked off" of a busy status (which is usually used to complete after call work) and thrown back into a "ready" status where you have to take inbounds
Long training process - it takes about 2 months to complete and is a bit dry (trainers are great, it's the material that's dry) 
Your performance is judged on the outcome of your files - donors who are unable to move forward in the donation process are counted "against" you
Heavy caseload - easily become burnt-out and creates tension within the teams
Most reps work outside of their normal scheduled hours, but we're only allowed 2 hours of overtime a week
Cliques within the Donor Operations Team
Donors can be extremely rude and inappropriate
You become emotionally invested and it can take a toll mentally
High turnover due to the above issues - also, people move to different departments quickly, which also creates a lot of turnover

pros: Wonderful co-workers. Awesome upper-level management. Very understanding and accomodating workspace. I love working here!
cons: Not much. As a non-profit, the pay isn't as good as industry.

cons: Leadership changes are often necessary to accelerate growth, but the past three years have been unusually difficult on our teams with executive leadership turnover (3rd CEO in 2 yrs). With the current CEO (promoted from CFO in June) there is hope for settling in on a focused, achievable strategy.

review_title: There are some great leaders who support development of their team members
pros: There are some great leaders who support development of their team members
cons: salary may be a little low

review_title: Massive turnover with employee rights violations business as usual
pros: Mission to save lives.
cons:
I worked at Be The Match for over 7 years.  There were times we could have been more innovative in order to help more patients.  However, the organization has taken a drastic turn over the last year where it seems to have lost its way.  The mission is no longer empowering, but utilized as a form of continual guilt.  The turnover both voluntary and involuntary is double to triple that of historical years.  People are being handed their severance papers on an almost daily basis for so called performance issues when there is little to no support in the form of performance improvement plans.  Then there are other cases like mine where leaders are flat out violating FMLA - telling me they would make no exceptions to the mandate for the upcoming policy change requiring all Minneapolis based leaders to be in the office everyday (no remote work).  This would overrule my informal accommodation that had been in place for 18+ months to support my autistic son (did I mention I was also promoted during that time?).  When I requested a formal accommodation, I was denied.  Further, my direct and indirect leaders would not give me anything in writing to show that my informal accommodation agreement would continue (nor any form of support...only bullying and evasion).   
The kicker is that my just announced replacement is full-time remote.

job_title: Integrated Marketing Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Motivated people, cool office, great cause
cons: Sporadic leadership, changing visions, role clarity problems

job_title: BE the Match- Search Coordinator in Alameda, CA
pros: They all employees to have an open workspace
cons: Does not compensate for the amount of work required for the position.

pros: Good benefits, CTO, good mission
cons: frequently change of management, lack of consistency

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Pay is good. Office well designed. Nice cafeteria
cons: No job training manual. Lack of good trainers. Poor structure. Lack of order, coordination.

review_title: Great company where you can make a difference
pros: Strong leadership team, great mission, and clear company goals
cons: Corporate politics, Lack of Diversity

pros: Many opportunities to grow in the marketing department
cons: Can be a crazy work environment sometimes.

pros: Great mission, Great benefits,Remote work
cons: Depending on position, things can get hectic. Work life balance can be hard

review_title: Change in leadership and structure; state of flux - otherwise, good place to work, but give it some time.
pros: Wonderful mission; loved being a part of something with such a great purpose and seeing the depth of generosity of many.  Great benefits. Enjoyed the ability to work remote and "dress for your day."  Dedicated staff, especially in departments directly touched by mission.
cons:
With leadership change and reorganization, atmosphere got too stressful and at times even painful, watching and hearing coworkers worry about losing jobs or having heavier workloads.  Decided to leave. 
Company has a tendency to hire from outside the org for upper levels; things can be redundant if "new" ideas really aren't.  Much starting and stopping; "worker bees" have a lot of knowledge from trial and error; upper management needs to listen to them.  
Saw some hesitancy about CEO; some love him, some think he says what staff want to hear. Needs time.

pros: I can’t really think of any.  If you like stress, poor middle management this is the place to work.
cons: It’s located in the north loop, parking is horrible unless your an executive then you get highly subsidized parking under the building.  The pay is below average with the performance that is expected.    There used to be a work from home option, but that’s now gone.   You get a tiny little desk with no storage and a locker on another floor,  if you need to get something from your locker you have to wait for the cheap slow elevator.  This is no opportunity for career growth and no training available.  The laptops they provided are beyond slow.   The pay is not the best,  unless you are a Director or higher.

review_title: Good place, good people, a bit unstable
pros: Very nice and dedicated people. Care about hearing ideas, even from those at the bottom. They listen and they are passionate.
cons: Entry level job got monatenous. Mainly left due to company instability and fear of layoffs. Wanted to get off what seemed like a potential sinking ship. Not a fun lovely culture, never did happy hours, or parties, etc. As a non-profit, though, you've kind of got to give that up.

pros: Good company mission .  Colorful chairs in cafeteria.
cons:
No clear plan for the future, employees don’t know long-term goals, senior leadership fails to adequately communicate. Focus is only on “A project “ princess syndrome.
Unfulfilled corporate expectations, employees report a lack of trust in Senior Management, inability to live up to brand promises. Favoritisms.
Pristine and ideal image in marketing materials and publicity, however, the day-to-day operation is far from glamorous. Only the leaders have what can pass as offices, staff is dispersed amongst shoddy or no cubicles and let’s not get started on the break room with no coffee machine, stinking microwaves.
Mangers using passive aggressive and obedience tactics used often in dog training on employees inadvertently building a hostile environment .

pros:
The NMDP lives and breathes its mission to save lives.
You'll never meet a nicer, kinder batch of co-workers. These people are all heart. Their annual meeting will bring you to tears (in a good way).
Decent benefits package - when was the last time you saw the words "pension" or "long-tern care insurance?" Also, the full-time hourly workweek is 37.5 hours instead of 40.
cons:
You'll never make the big dollars at the NMDP - it is a non-profit, after all.
Very regulated business, lots of rules, progress moves very cautiously and takes a long time.
Very conservative funding for any corporate initiatives means no risk-taking, no extra staff, and no capital expenditures. You have to work with what you've got, or wait until next year's budget cycle to get funding, which will certainly be cut by 10% if you get approval at all.

review_title: No longer the best place to work
pros: Wonderful mission and good employees.  Reasonable work hours and compensation.  Low turnover.  The environment was supportive and employees generally liked each other.  It used to be the best place to work.  Employees were always willing to go above and beyond for the company and their colleagues.
cons: New IT senior leadership is deplorable.  Little to no chance for advancement.  Low raises.  The work environment has changed considerably - now, employees do not like each other and there is a lot of back stabbing.  New IT senior leadership shows little respect for long term employees.  The future direction is uncertain.  Constructive feedback from employees is not welcome.

pros: Great mission, great people to work with.  Benefits are really good for a non-profit.
cons: Spending is out of control.  Annual meeting, board member trips, expenses, IT software implementations/upgrades (Oracle), use of contractors (esp in IT).  Bloated organization.  Look at all of the office locations, it's completely wasteful. Now they are moving from their beautiful building (that cost a fortune to build out and move in to) to near the Twins stadium? How in the heck does a "nonprofit" afford all of this?

pros: I was really impressed with the level of dedication and commitment exhibited by the entire staff.  It's not just a job for the people who work there, it's a commitment to helping others.  I found management to be dedicated and transparent and earnestly interested in the organization's and staff's well-being.
cons: The shifting health care environment made it difficult to plan for the future so you are sometimes left with plans that become unworkable.  There can be a bit of a silo-effect when departments don't work well with each other.

review_title: Great position, great team, great mission
pros:
- Mission-oriented organization 
- Company overall states their interest in fostering employees' personal growth, though it really comes down to teams and team leaders/managers - on a team level where I am though, there is certainly an interest in professional growth & development of individuals on the team
- Good benefits
cons: - At the moment, for me - none. However, I work in a smaller, somewhat isolated department. More generally, communication from top down is often scattered, inconsistent, and - in some cases - misleading.

review_title: Depends on what you are looking for in a job
pros: My department has great work/life balance. Working from home. Amazing coworkers. Taking time off is never questioned. Love the new building.
cons: Difficult to get promoted. Some positions need a very specific degree and experience within the company doesn't matter. Too strict on putting in 8 hours a day. If I am done after 6 or 7 hours, I have to take vacation time to leave.

pros: Excellent total compensation package; opportunities to work flexibly/remotely.
cons: Current executive leadership with questionable authoritarian tactics and lack of true transparency...a distinct departure from previous history.  Organizational culture has subsequently dissolved to a state of chaos, bewilderment, and uncertainty.

review_title: Suffocated and Powerless - NEED TO CHANGE.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
- What the company does.
- Work from home policy
- Good amenities (cafeteria)
- Dress code.
cons:
-Bureaucracy
-Dictatorial Middle Management
-Lack of Solid Career Ladder

pros:
Extremely friendly staff! This particular department is about 95% women (at least when I still worked there). Encouraged you to improve yourself. Helping others. Can work from home up to 3 days per week. Awesome benefits right away.

I have heard numerous times other departments are much better to work in.
cons: There are minimal ways to be promoted. There are MANY case managers, and the next step up would be a team lead-only 1 for each 4-5 teams. Each team is lead by a manager. Then it's the director and VP of the department. That's it. So if you don't have additional skills to be used in other departments you're kind of stuck.

pros: They built a great office space on the Blue Line, but of you need to park it's not good or cheap--unless Director-level or above, then free underground space.  Benefits are very good.  Pay tends to be at lower ranges if you accept their reason of "We're a not-for-profit organization" but if they are motivated, they will come up.   Work from home option is outstanding perk!  Almost everyone works from home two days per week; usually Monday and Friday.  No weekends or holidays if in office.
cons: Leaders are old original staff from 1980s, who came from experience in medicine or academia; not one ever ran profitable, efficient operations outside of the organization.  They are so ignorant of modern-day business and HR practices they do not have a clue to why their same practices have failed to meet goals since 2009---they just write new ones and BS how they will change---until the next report of sub-par results is due.  It's bizarre to come from private (who have limited budgets based on performance, not fund raising and grant writing.)

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Of course the mission is compelling! IT teams using scrum / agile. Awesome new building in downtown Minneapolis. Most teams have some work from home and the dress code is basically jeans. Benefits are pretty good.
cons: Career development is lacking, organization always trying to do too many IT projects at once. Working across teams can be frustrating and slow. New building's openness can be distracting.

job_title: Clinical Project Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Organization's mission is second to none. Your work truly impacts the lives of patients in desperate need of a cure. Teams are small and your contribution and influence goes a long way once trust is established.
cons: Workload for some roles is significantly higher than some. Compared to industry, salaries are low, and much more is expected of you. Staff can be spread thin and burnout is a risk.

review_title: Why did it have to take so long?

cons: FINALLY they have replaced some toxic managers in FP&A.  But good people have left the org in the meantime.    If they had the courage to make the changes when whey were apparent 3 to 4 years ago, a lot of talent could've been retained.

review_title: Trust is Preached Not Practiced, Manipulative leadership

cons: Frequent reorganizations. Expecting manager or supervisor to change every few months.  Processes and tasks change even more frequently. Fearing that raising concerns or not showing avid agreement will get you fired.
